awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Using Mycelium As A Matrix For Binding Natural Fibers And Core Filler Materials In Sustainable Composites
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project seeks to address the steadily growing but unsustainable polymer matrix composite (PMC) market. PMCs are leveraged for their high strength-to-weight and stiffness-to-weight ratios as compared to conventional engineering materials, but are notoriously unsustainable, energy-intensive to manufacture, and non-recyclable.  Researchers have investigated encapsulating natural fibers with both petroleum-based polymers and biopolymers (e.g. cellulosic plastic) to produce more biocompatible composites with varying degrees of experimental and commercial success, but all attempts have still fallen short of an ideal "bio-composite". In this project, we will create and characterize an entirely new bio-composite material. The basic idea is to use mycelium as a matrix for binding natural fibers and core filler materials together in sustainable composite parts.  First, the core bulk material is bound together over time by mycelium growing into and around common bulk agricultural waste such as cotton hulls.  Then, reinforcing layers made from natural fibers (e.g., hemp) inoculated with fungal cells are applied to the core faces, allowed to infiltrate the laminate and bind to the core material, and then heated to inactivate the growth process to make a resilient composite sandwich structure.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project encompasses the development of mycelium composite materials that are customizable for a broad range of markets including, but not limited to, automotive, transportation, architectural, biomedical, sports, and recreation. These materials are truly sustainable since both the laminates and cores consist of renewable materials.  These composites will also require significantly less energy to make than other biocompatible composites because the material is grown instead of synthesized, and the material is completely compostable at the end of life. The outcome of the proposed research and development will be a basic understanding of how to manufacture the composites, the range of material properties obtainable, and how to adjust material properties for particular markets. Through this project, we will partner with researchers and students at two local universities with known expertise in composites manufacturing and testing. If successful with mycelium composites, these materials will find applications in a very high-margin market (i.e. composites) that is sorely needing more sustainable innovations.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Natural fibers have proven to be successful replacements for synthetic fibers in advanced composite applications ranging from transportation and construction to consumer products. However, the full potential of natural fiber reinforced composites (FRCs) has not been fully realized commercially due to the difficulties that arise when conventional engineering polymers are introduced as matrix materials. Rather than modifying natural fibers to meet the challenging demands of conventional polymer processing (e.g., high temperature processing leading to fiber biodegradation), Ecovative Design, LLC has engineered a unique, grown biopolymer that not only meets the same high-performance demands of traditional FRCs, but is also made from domestic renewable resources, and is biodegradable or recyclable at end of life (materials can be effectively reprocessed into new material with minimal effort). These mycological composites are currently at a competitive price point to their incumbent counterparts, making them a viable, cost-effective, and environmentally friendly alternative.

 

Phase I funding was used to undertake a feasibility study to establish the best markets for a new MycoBond™ composite sandwich by quantifying the growth rates of the filamentous fungus biopolymer and characterizing the physical and mechanical properties of the resulting natural FRC structure. To begin, the mycological bio-composite core was fabricated on Ecovative’s production system (designed for a protective packaging product that leverages the same biopolymer) and incubated in Ecovative’s Spawn Laboratory. The biopolymer consists of the vegetative tissue (mycelium) of a basidiomycete, a lignin degrading white rot decomposer. It grows exponentially by consuming a proprietary blend of cellulose and lignin containing agricultural byproducts. The resulting structure is a system of highly branched, interwoven hyphal networks, which composes Ecovative’s patented core material. Two different species of fungi were originally selected in the Phase I proposal; however, only the one species was used during the entirety of the work plan due to poor growth noted in the early tasks.

 

Once the engineered core material was fabricated, a rigorous screening design of experiments (DOE) was conducted to determine the optimum laminate structure. The first round DOE tested the MycoBond core material with two different plant-based fiber types, jute and hemp. These lignocellulosic fibers contain an average of 22.9% and 5% lignin, respectively. Three fiber forms were studied, including chopped strand mat, woven, and pre-tensioned woven. The post-processing (plasticized or none) and drying conditions (normal or compressed) were varied to observe what affect these factors had on the material properties. The specimens were then cut to size for a series of physical and mechanical properties tests to determine the best performance options based on the results below.

 

Performance metrics were measured according to the American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) standards, where applicable. The core material was tested in compression, according to ASTM D695 using a cage fixture configuration and the compressive modulus was determined using the best fit slope of the compressive engineering stress versus engineering strain curve. The 2-ply fiber skin, colonized with mycelium was tested in tension and the stiffness was measured based on ASTM D3039 using the best fit slope of tensile load versus engineering tensile strain curve. The bio-composite sandwich was then tested in flexure via three point bending (ASTM C393) and the stiffness was derived based on the best-fit slope of the bending load versus crosshead position plot. All data was compiled and a one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was performed.

 

The bio-composite d...
